values.description:
* Port actor meshes from [citysim](#!/osrf/citysim)
* Add `service.world.erb`, which has the Willow Garage model as a placeholder
* A template file for actor animations which idle in place (`actor_idle.erb`)
* Two example files (`idle_*.erb`) to populate `actor_idle.erb`, they were generated with a plugin which will come in a future PR (currently in branch `actor_plugin`)


Added rough instructions to the wiki page, will be improving it as we go:

#!/osrf/servicesim/wiki/Installation


![willow1.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/3206678163-willow1.png)
values.title: Initial ERB files

values.description:
This creates 3 packages (mostly placeholders for now):
- servicesim : the high level package users will interact with
- servicesim_competition: package to store plugins, world, ROS interfaces, models used for servicesim competition
- servicebot description: Robot description that will contain meshes, urdf etc

Right now I just dumped the tortoisebot urdf to be able to move this forward and unblock other PRs, I'll update it with the servicebot model and meshes in a follow-up PR.
There are some dummy launchfiles to get started. 
Calling `roslaunch servicesim servicesim` will launch gazebo with an empty world via `sevicesim_competition` and load the servicebot model via `servicebot_description`
values.title: create packages and move existing files in them

Right now I just dumped the tortoisebot urdf to be able to move this forward and unblock other PRs, I'll update it with the servicebot model and meshes in a follow-up PR.
There are some dummy launchfiles to get started. 
Calling `roslaunch servicesim servicesim` will launch gazebo with an empty world via `sevicesim_competition` and load the servicebot model via `servicebot_description`

Right now I just dumped the tortoisebot urdf to be able to move this forward and unblock other PRs, I'll update it with the servicebot model and meshes in a follow-up PR. values.description:
Add `TrajectoryActorPlugin` and related ERB files.

* Supports running and walking animations
* Plugin accepts a list of target poses in the world.
* Actor stops if there's an obstacle on the way:

![stop.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/799210280-stop.gif)

* Unlike when using the actor's <script> tag, actors make smooth tight corners:

![curve.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/2285667575-curve.gif)

* Velocity, animation, skin, trajectory all configurable through ERB, see the 2 examples `trajectory_back` and `trajectory_front`. They were generated using a GUI plugin which I'll add in a future PR.

There is room for improvement in the plugin, it currently assumes the actors will have Y-up. This works for our animations, but I'd like to make this more general in the future
values.title: Actors with scripted trajectories

summary.raw:
Add `TrajectoryActorPlugin` and related ERB files.

* Supports running and walking animations
* Plugin accepts a list of target poses in the world.
* Actor stops if there's an obstacle on the way:

![stop.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/799210280-stop.gif)

* Unlike when using the actor's <script> tag, actors make smooth tight corners:

![curve.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/2285667575-curve.gif)

* Velocity, animation, skin, trajectory all configurable through ERB, see the 2 examples `trajectory_back` and `trajectory_front`. They were generated using a GUI plugin which I'll add in a future PR.

There is room for improvement in the plugin, it currently assumes the actors will have Y-up. This works for our animations, but I'd like to make this more general in the future
summary.html:
Add TrajectoryActorPlugin and related ERB files.

  • Supports running and walking animations
  • Plugin accepts a list of target poses in the world.
  • Actor stops if there's an obstacle on the way:

  • Unlike when using the actor's <script> tag, actors make smooth tight corners:

  • Velocity, animation, skin, trajectory all configurable through ERB, see the 2 examples trajectory_back and trajectory_front. They were generated using a GUI plugin which I'll add in a future PR.

There is room for improvement in the plugin, it currently assumes the actors will have Y-up. This works for our animations, but I'd like to make this more general in the future

values.description:
Added instructions to the wiki:

#!/osrf/servicesim/wiki/Walkthrough

The plugin accepts a list of absolute sim times when the guest should drift away. These are randomized on `service.world.erb`, I just used some placeholder numbers for now, we can fine-tune it later.

You can try it out following the instructions on the wiki and manually moving the robot, in the example world the robot drifts away (stops following) at 10 seconds sim time:

![drift.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/3632962900-drift.gif)
values.title: Follow plugin

values.description:
Redo of pull request #6 which doesn't use ROS. 

The ROS interface will be kept for the user-facing features, and simulation internals are being done in Ignition Transport.

After doing a catkin isolated install, you can run the demo world from the root of your workspace like this:


~~~
GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH=$GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH:`pwd`/install_isolated/share/servicesim_competition/models gazebo --verbose install_isolated/share/servicesim_competition/worlds/follow_actor_demo.world
~~~


![follow.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/1581373785-follow.gif)

There is some documentation on the plugin header, let me know if something is missing or unclear.

@mikaelarguedas it would be great if you could poke around this PR. Beware that ign-transport's command line tools don't work unless you compile ign-transport3 from source together with [ign-tools](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-tools).
values.title: Actor follow plugin using Ignition transport

The ROS interface will be kept for the user-facing features, and simulation internals are being done in Ignition Transport.

~~~

There is some documentation on the plugin header, let me know if something is missing or unclear.

summary.html:
Redo of pull request #6 which doesn't use ROS.

The ROS interface will be kept for the user-facing features, and simulation internals are being done in Ignition Transport.

After doing a catkin isolated install, you can run the demo world from the root of your workspace like this:

GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH=$GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH:`pwd`/install_isolated/share/servicesim_competition/models gazebo --verbose install_isolated/share/servicesim_competition/worlds/follow_actor_demo.world

There is some documentation on the plugin header, let me know if something is missing or unclear.

@mikaelarguedas it would be great if you could poke around this PR. Beware that ign-transport's command line tools don't work unless you compile ign-transport3 from source together with ign-tools.

values.description:
* General structure of competition plugin
* One checkpoint: go to pick-up area, with an area hardcoded on the SDF
* Time-based score
* This requires Gazebo 8.3 to fully work, that should be released in the coming days. Until then, the code will compile and run, but Gazebo will say it can't find `libContainPlugin.so`, so the checkpoint can't be completed
* Everything on the [Walkthrough](#!/osrf/servicesim/wiki/Walkthrough) should work up to checkpoint 1, including:

    * `rostopic echo /servicesim/score`
    * `rosservice call /servicesim/new_task`
values.title: Competition - part 1

    • rostopic echo /servicesim/score
    • rosservice call /servicesim/new_task

values.description:
With this PR, it is possible to follow the whole [walkthrough](#!/osrf/servicesim/wiki/Walkthrough).

## Pick-up checkpoint

* Provides the `/servicesim/pick_up_guest` ROS service
* Calls the `/servicesim/guest/follow` Ignition service
* Can be restarted multiple times if the guest drifts while attempting the following checkpoint

## Drop-off checkpoint

* Provides the `/servicesim/drop_off_guest` ROS service
* Monitors the `/servicesim/guest/drift` Ignition service and pauses the checkpoint when drift occurs
* Monitors `/servicesim/drop_off/contain` Ignition topic to check whether the guest has reached the drop-off room

## Return to start checkpoint

* Monitors `/servicesim/return_to_start/contain` Ignition topic to check whether the guest has reached the drop-off area
values.title: More checkpoints

summary.raw:
With this PR, it is possible to follow the whole [walkthrough](#!/osrf/servicesim/wiki/Walkthrough).

## Pick-up checkpoint

* Provides the `/servicesim/pick_up_guest` ROS service
* Calls the `/servicesim/guest/follow` Ignition service
* Can be restarted multiple times if the guest drifts while attempting the following checkpoint

## Drop-off checkpoint

* Provides the `/servicesim/drop_off_guest` ROS service
* Monitors the `/servicesim/guest/drift` Ignition service and pauses the checkpoint when drift occurs
* Monitors `/servicesim/drop_off/contain` Ignition topic to check whether the guest has reached the drop-off room

## Return to start checkpoint

* Monitors `/servicesim/return_to_start/contain` Ignition topic to check whether the guest has reached the drop-off area
summary.html:
With this PR, it is possible to follow the whole walkthrough.

Pick-up checkpoint

  • Provides the /servicesim/pick_up_guest ROS service
  • Calls the /servicesim/guest/follow Ignition service
  • Can be restarted multiple times if the guest drifts while attempting the following checkpoint

Drop-off checkpoint

  • Provides the /servicesim/drop_off_guest ROS service
  • Monitors the /servicesim/guest/drift Ignition service and pauses the checkpoint when drift occurs
  • Monitors /servicesim/drop_off/contain Ignition topic to check whether the guest has reached the drop-off room

Return to start checkpoint

  • Monitors /servicesim/return_to_start/contain Ignition topic to check whether the guest has reached the drop-off area

values.description:
* add max acceleration to wheels

* add front/rear camera frames and sensors

* add IMU and lidar

* controllers for the head joints

* add rviz and rqt configuration files

* fix(ate) arm links

* publish caster wheel joints state

Note: the robot doesn't drive straight anymore (rotation on the spot works well though), the Z pose of all the wheels collision is the same so I'm not sure why wheels only sporadically contact with the floor. The wheels use spheres as collision shapes but are attached to only 1 axis rotation joints, so maybe that's part of the issue
values.title: Add sensors and controllers

summary.raw:
* add max acceleration to wheels

* add front/rear camera frames and sensors

* add IMU and lidar

* controllers for the head joints

* add rviz and rqt configuration files

* fix(ate) arm links

* publish caster wheel joints state

Note: the robot doesn't drive straight anymore (rotation on the spot works well though), the Z pose of all the wheels collision is the same so I'm not sure why wheels only sporadically contact with the floor. The wheels use spheres as collision shapes but are attached to only 1 axis rotation joints, so maybe that's part of the issue
summary.html:
• add max acceleration to wheels

  • add front/rear camera frames and sensors

  • add IMU and lidar

  • controllers for the head joints

  • add rviz and rqt configuration files

  • fix(ate) arm links

  • publish caster wheel joints state

Note: the robot doesn't drive straight anymore (rotation on the spot works well though), the Z pose of all the wheels collision is the same so I'm not sure why wheels only sporadically contact with the floor. The wheels use spheres as collision shapes but are attached to only 1 axis rotation joints, so maybe that's part of the issue

values.description:
@rohitsalem , this pull request adds a world with only the things which should show up on the occupancy grid, such as room, walls and cubicles.

It was generated from `servicesim.world.erb`, but I'm handling other issues there right now, so I'm only committing the generated file, which shouldn't change.

You should be able to load it like this:

1. Source Gazebo 8's setup file (important because we'll be setting `GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH`). From a debian install, it should be:

        . /usr/share/gazebo-8/setup.sh

1. Move to the competition folder and load Gazebo like this:

        GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH=`pwd`/models:$GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH=`pwd`/media:$GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH gazebo --verbose worlds/floorplan.world

You should see this world:

![floorplan.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/3170248820-floorplan.png)

Let me know if you run into any problems or see anything fishy on the world.
values.title: Floorplan world

  2. Move to the competition folder and load Gazebo like this:

You should see this world:

Let me know if you run into any problems or see anything fishy on the world.

values.description:
Pull request #20 is part of this one.

* Remove `willowgarage`
* Change guest, robot and idling actor poses accordingly
* Removing trajectory actors for now, the trajectories need to be regenerated and the obstacle detection needs to be tweaked to handle the rooms
* Also disabled obstacle detection on the guest (`FollowActorPlugin`) for now so they can enter rooms
* Changed world name to `default` because of [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/2053/topic-name-mismatch-on-heavy-worlds-with) Gazebo issue
* Added a parameter to generate a world with only the floorplan, i.e.:

        erb f=true worlds/service.world.erb >  worlds/floorplan.world


![newoffice.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/1549557767-newoffice.gif)
values.title: New office, first pass

summary.raw:
Pull request #20 is part of this one.

* Remove `willowgarage`
* Change guest, robot and idling actor poses accordingly
* Removing trajectory actors for now, the trajectories need to be regenerated and the obstacle detection needs to be tweaked to handle the rooms
* Also disabled obstacle detection on the guest (`FollowActorPlugin`) for now so they can enter rooms
* Changed world name to `default` because of [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/2053/topic-name-mismatch-on-heavy-worlds-with) Gazebo issue
* Added a parameter to generate a world with only the floorplan, i.e.:

        erb f=true worlds/service.world.erb >  worlds/floorplan.world


![newoffice.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/1549557767-newoffice.gif)
summary.html:
Pull request #20 is part of this one.

  • Remove willowgarage
  • Change guest, robot and idling actor poses accordingly
  • Removing trajectory actors for now, the trajectories need to be regenerated and the obstacle detection needs to be tweaked to handle the rooms
  • Also disabled obstacle detection on the guest (FollowActorPlugin) for now so they can enter rooms
  • Changed world name to default because of this Gazebo issue

  • Added a parameter to generate a world with only the floorplan, i.e.:

    erb f=true worlds/service.world.erb >  worlds/floorplan.world

values.description:
Remove xacro from cmakelists.

#!/osrf/servicesim/commits/e95b5cd6536553b500d737696ad276cc0c4bdf4c?at=default removes xacro as a dependency but it's still listed in CMake and so still looked for during a build.

See https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/servicesim-ci-xenial-amd64/11/ for an example failure.

To my neophyte eyes it doesn't appear that xacro is used here anymore but I could be wrong.
values.title: Remove xacro from cmakelists.

summary.raw:
Remove xacro from cmakelists.

#!/osrf/servicesim/commits/e95b5cd6536553b500d737696ad276cc0c4bdf4c?at=default removes xacro as a dependency but it's still listed in CMake and so still looked for during a build.

See https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/servicesim-ci-xenial-amd64/11/ for an example failure.

To my neophyte eyes it doesn't appear that xacro is used here anymore but I could be wrong.
summary.html:
Remove xacro from cmakelists.

#!/osrf/servicesim/commits/e95b5cd6536553b500d737696ad276cc0c4bdf4c?at=default removes xacro as a dependency but it's still listed in CMake and so still looked for during a build.

See https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/servicesim-ci-xenial-amd64/11/ for an example failure.

To my neophyte eyes it doesn't appear that xacro is used here anymore but I could be wrong.

values.description:
Ogre complains about accessing submeshes hundreds of times, so I broke the door and cubicle wall into separate obj meshes

Also fix sink material.

Also fix sink material.

values.description:
* Port `cardboard_box` from the model database, rename it to `office_box` to avoid collisions, make it static and in a better pose for our use
* Increase mini-fridge scale (it was toooo mini)
* Rotate a few other models so they all face +X and can follow the same logic when being inserted
values.title: Tweak objects used on room corners

summary.raw:
* Port `cardboard_box` from the model database, rename it to `office_box` to avoid collisions, make it static and in a better pose for our use
* Increase mini-fridge scale (it was toooo mini)
* Rotate a few other models so they all face +X and can follow the same logic when being inserted
summary.html:
• Port cardboard_box from the model database, rename it to office_box to avoid collisions, make it static and in a better pose for our use
  • Increase mini-fridge scale (it was toooo mini)
  • Rotate a few other models so they all face +X and can follow the same logic when being inserted

values.description:
## Obstacles

The original obstacle detection for actors doesn't work well for the new rooms, because actors will go inside the room's bounding box, but shouldn't collide with walls.

I'm disabling it now for the guest, and completely commenting out the trajectory actors as their trajectories will need to be recalculated for the new map anyway.

## Lights

A single directional light doesn't play well with an indoor environment. For now, I'm going for ambient lighting, but that means we have no shadows. In the future, we could look into having a few different lights, or even a better single directional light.

The new light looks horrible for willowgarage, but will be nice for the new office.
values.title: Disable obstacle detection and use ambient lighting instead of a directional light

summary.raw:
## Obstacles

The original obstacle detection for actors doesn't work well for the new rooms, because actors will go inside the room's bounding box, but shouldn't collide with walls.

I'm disabling it now for the guest, and completely commenting out the trajectory actors as their trajectories will need to be recalculated for the new map anyway.

## Lights

A single directional light doesn't play well with an indoor environment. For now, I'm going for ambient lighting, but that means we have no shadows. In the future, we could look into having a few different lights, or even a better single directional light.

The new light looks horrible for willowgarage, but will be nice for the new office.
summary.html:
Obstacles

The original obstacle detection for actors doesn't work well for the new rooms, because actors will go inside the room's bounding box, but shouldn't collide with walls.

I'm disabling it now for the guest, and completely commenting out the trajectory actors as their trajectories will need to be recalculated for the new map anyway.

Lights

A single directional light doesn't play well with an indoor environment. For now, I'm going for ambient lighting, but that means we have no shadows. In the future, we could look into having a few different lights, or even a better single directional light.

The new light looks horrible for willowgarage, but will be nice for the new office.

values.description:
This is a subset of pull request #21:

* Remove `willowgarage` model
* Add floor and ceiling
* Add extra walls which go around the rooms
* Move idling actors into new office
* Move guest
* Move robot spawning pose
* Add `$(find servicesim_competition)` to resource path so Gazebo finds materials inside `media` folder

![wallsonly.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/2367121897-wallsonly.gif)
values.title: New office: walls, ceiling and floor

values.description:
This is a follow-up to #!/osrf/servicesim/pull-requests/40 which I committed feedback changes to and then did not build locally to check. I'm going to merge the PR if it passes CI but I'm happy to take post-merge review if this isn't actually the right fix.

This is action is taken in response to the error message below

```
CMake Error at /opt/ros/kinetic/share/catkin/cmake/catkin_package.cmake:224 (message):
  catkin_package() DEPENDS on the catkin package 'roscpp' which must
  therefore be listed as a run dependency in the package.xml
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  /opt/ros/kinetic/share/catkin/cmake/catkin_package.cmake:102 (_catkin_package)
  CMakeLists.txt:35 (catkin_package)
```

I am pretty sure adding the run dependency on roscpp is the right way to go based on the catkin tutorials.
values.title: Fix for roscpp dependency error and depend on gazebo at runtime.

Call Stack (most recent call first):

I am pretty sure adding the run dependency on roscpp is the right way to go based on the catkin tutorials.

This is a follow-up to #!/osrf/servicesim/pull-requests/40 which I committed feedback changes to and then did not build locally to check. I'm going to merge the PR if it passes CI but I'm happy to take post-merge review if this isn't actually the right fix.

This is action is taken in response to the error message below

CMake Error at /opt/ros/kinetic/share/catkin/cmake/catkin_package.cmake:224 (message):
  catkin_package() DEPENDS on the catkin package 'roscpp' which must
  therefore be listed as a run dependency in the package.xml
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  /opt/ros/kinetic/share/catkin/cmake/catkin_package.cmake:102 (_catkin_package)
  CMakeLists.txt:35 (catkin_package)

I am pretty sure adding the run dependency on roscpp is the right way to go based on the catkin tutorials.

values.description:
Add several pick/drop target areas around the map.

Pass `d=true` when generating the world from ERB so the world has visuals for debugging:

* A red box for each target area
* A blue cylinder for each target area's minimum point
* A green cylinder for each target area's maximum point

![dropareas.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/1739583596-dropareas.gif)

## Areas

* Rooms with closed doors can't be targets
* Most room's areas are the whole space inside of the room
* Bathrooms are the only rooms whose areas are outside of the door, so the robot doesn't need to enter the bathroom with the guest

![areas_2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/1293238926-areas_2.png)

* The private cubicles areas consist of the whole cubicle (probably too hard to get in) and a 1m rectangle in front of the cubicle

![area_cubicles.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/3044902187-area_cubicles.png)

* The public cubicle areas consist of a rectangle around them:

![areas_3.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/924170597-areas_3.png)

* The front entrance consists of 3 separate areas:

![areas_4.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/2252747865-areas_4.png)

## Service

I added instructions to the wiki's [API](#!/osrf/servicesim/wiki/API) and [walkthrough](#!/osrf/servicesim/wiki/Walkthrough). Try calling like this for example:

    rosservice call /servicesim/room_info PrivateCafe

## Guest / robot placement

Each room has a placement point where the guest or robot can be spawned at startup. These are visible as orange cylinders on the debug world:

![locations2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/834612935-locations2.png)

Other locations:

* Guest initial pose (yellow)

* Drop-off room (magenta)

* Robot start pose (cyan) - **TODO** robot is not being spawned there yet, must sync this with URDF

![locations.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/2940860510-locations.png)
values.title: Room names

summary.html:
Add several pick/drop target areas around the map.

Pass d=true when generating the world from ERB so the world has visuals for debugging:

  • A red box for each target area
  • A blue cylinder for each target area's minimum point
  • A green cylinder for each target area's maximum point

Areas

  • Rooms with closed doors can't be targets
  • Most room's areas are the whole space inside of the room
  • Bathrooms are the only rooms whose areas are outside of the door, so the robot doesn't need to enter the bathroom with the guest

  • The private cubicles areas consist of the whole cubicle (probably too hard to get in) and a 1m rectangle in front of the cubicle

  • The public cubicle areas consist of a rectangle around them:

  • The front entrance consists of 3 separate areas:

Service

I added instructions to the wiki's API and walkthrough. Try calling like this for example:

rosservice call /servicesim/room_info PrivateCafe

Guest / robot placement

Each room has a placement point where the guest or robot can be spawned at startup. These are visible as orange cylinders on the debug world:

Other locations:

  • Guest initial pose (yellow)

  • Drop-off room (magenta)

  • Robot start pose (cyan) - TODO robot is not being spawned there yet, must sync this with URDF

values.description:
This builds on top of pull request #44

### Motivation

We need to spawn the robot at a specific location in the world, and we also need to create a checkpoint on that location. It would also be nice to have that location automatically picked as the world file is generated.

Currently, the robot spawn coordinates are being passed to a `spawn_model` node on `servicesim.launch`, but the coordinates are being generated and passed to plugins on `service.world.erb`.

This pull request moves the spawn logic to the world SDF file so that the robot is spawned in the appropriate location without the need to keep multiple generated files in sync.

### Approach

To find a model includes in the world using an `<include>` tag and a uri in the `model://robotname` format, Gazebo needs:

1. To find a `model.config` file within one of the `<path>`s in `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH`: `<path>/robotname/model.config`
1. To find the meshes which take the format `model://...../*.obj` also within a `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH`.

Since the URDF parsing translates `package://servicebot_description/meshes` to `model://servicebot_description/meshes`, we need the parent directory of `servicebot_description` to be in the path to satisfy 2.

So we might as well also add our `model.config` file under `servicebot_description` because that will be in the path.

So:

1. Add a `model.config` to the `*_description` package and point to the `urdf/*.urdf` model in `<sdf>`
1. Pass the parent dir of `*_description` to `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH`
1. Include `model://*_description` in the SDF world
values.title: Include robot URDF into SDF world (remove spawn_model node)

summary.raw:
This builds on top of pull request #44

### Motivation

We need to spawn the robot at a specific location in the world, and we also need to create a checkpoint on that location. It would also be nice to have that location automatically picked as the world file is generated.

Currently, the robot spawn coordinates are being passed to a `spawn_model` node on `servicesim.launch`, but the coordinates are being generated and passed to plugins on `service.world.erb`.

This pull request moves the spawn logic to the world SDF file so that the robot is spawned in the appropriate location without the need to keep multiple generated files in sync.

### Approach

To find a model includes in the world using an `<include>` tag and a uri in the `model://robotname` format, Gazebo needs:

1. To find a `model.config` file within one of the `<path>`s in `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH`: `<path>/robotname/model.config`
1. To find the meshes which take the format `model://...../*.obj` also within a `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH`.

Since the URDF parsing translates `package://servicebot_description/meshes` to `model://servicebot_description/meshes`, we need the parent directory of `servicebot_description` to be in the path to satisfy 2.

So we might as well also add our `model.config` file under `servicebot_description` because that will be in the path.

So:

1. Add a `model.config` to the `*_description` package and point to the `urdf/*.urdf` model in `<sdf>`
1. Pass the parent dir of `*_description` to `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH`
1. Include `model://*_description` in the SDF world
summary.html:
This builds on top of pull request #44

Motivation

We need to spawn the robot at a specific location in the world, and we also need to create a checkpoint on that location. It would also be nice to have that location automatically picked as the world file is generated.

Currently, the robot spawn coordinates are being passed to a spawn_model node on servicesim.launch, but the coordinates are being generated and passed to plugins on service.world.erb.

This pull request moves the spawn logic to the world SDF file so that the robot is spawned in the appropriate location without the need to keep multiple generated files in sync.

Approach

To find a model includes in the world using an <include> tag and a uri in the model://robotname format, Gazebo needs:

  1. To find a model.config file within one of the <path>s in GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH: <path>/robotname/model.config
  2. To find the meshes which take the format model://...../*.obj also within a GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH.

Since the URDF parsing translates package://servicebot_description/meshes to model://servicebot_description/meshes, we need the parent directory of servicebot_description to be in the path to satisfy 2.

So we might as well also add our model.config file under servicebot_description because that will be in the path.

So:

  1. Add a model.config to the *_description package and point to the urdf/*.urdf model in <sdf>
  2. Pass the parent dir of *_description to GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH
  3. Include model://*_description in the SDF world

values.description:
This superseeds #!/osrf/servicesim/pull-requests/32.
This adds a new directory "competitor_example_solution" for the an example solution to solve the task:
- servicebot_2dnav: a nav stack configuration for servicebot
- example_python_solution: a python script showing a basic example of how to solve the task (tested on the world without furniture: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1YPZaV93ZDUSwR5oDulFIGvIZvV_iDu4z)

I merged default into that branch and tried to cancel my changes to the world file. As bitbucket cannot display it I don;t think that's been successful... Is there a way to just remove all changes to a given file in bitbucket ?
values.title: Example solution

summary.raw:
This superseeds #!/osrf/servicesim/pull-requests/32.
This adds a new directory "competitor_example_solution" for the an example solution to solve the task:
- servicebot_2dnav: a nav stack configuration for servicebot
- example_python_solution: a python script showing a basic example of how to solve the task (tested on the world without furniture: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1YPZaV93ZDUSwR5oDulFIGvIZvV_iDu4z)

I merged default into that branch and tried to cancel my changes to the world file. As bitbucket cannot display it I don;t think that's been successful... Is there a way to just remove all changes to a given file in bitbucket ?
summary.html:
This superseeds #!/osrf/servicesim/pull-requests/32. This adds a new directory "competitor_example_solution" for the an example solution to solve the task: - servicebot_2dnav: a nav stack configuration for servicebot - example_python_solution: a python script showing a basic example of how to solve the task (tested on the world without furniture: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1YPZaV93ZDUSwR5oDulFIGvIZvV_iDu4z)

I merged default into that branch and tried to cancel my changes to the world file. As bitbucket cannot display it I don;t think that's been successful... Is there a way to just remove all changes to a given file in bitbucket ?

values.title: create individual launchfiles for all groups

values.description:
Porting the example plugin which was added to Gazebo 8 on [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2875/example-plugin-that-enables-collisions/diff) pull request.

Right now, collisions are enabled for idle / trajectory actors, and for the guest. We may want to disable some of these in the future.

The Gazebo pull request has already been reviewed, so I'll wait for CI and then merge this one, because it is needed for penalties.

Slap!

 ![robotabuseopt.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/2628116256-robotabuseopt.gif)
values.title: Actor collisions

summary.raw:

Right now, collisions are enabled for idle / trajectory actors, and for the guest. We may want to disable some of these in the future.

The Gazebo pull request has already been reviewed, so I'll wait for CI and then merge this one, because it is needed for penalties.

Slap!

summary.html:
Porting the example plugin which was added to Gazebo 8 on this pull request.

Right now, collisions are enabled for idle / trajectory actors, and for the guest. We may want to disable some of these in the future.

The Gazebo pull request has already been reviewed, so I'll wait for CI and then merge this one, because it is needed for penalties.

Slap!

values.description:
Penalties with configurable weights for:

* A bad pick-up request
* A bad drop-off request
* Moving too fast that the actor stops following
* Colliding with humans
* Colliding with objects

![penalty_opt.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/3699591879-penalty_opt.gif)

Also:

* Removed detailed ROS score not to give away info to competitors
* Give every human a randomized name with the same pattern (`human_XXXXX`)
values.title: Penalties

summary.html:
Penalties with configurable weights for:

  • A bad pick-up request
  • A bad drop-off request
  • Moving too fast that the actor stops following
  • Colliding with humans
  • Colliding with objects

Also:

  • Removed detailed ROS score not to give away info to competitors
  • Give every human a randomized name with the same pattern (human_XXXXX)
